awd_titl_txt: RAPID: Supreme Court Support and Democratic Values
awd_abstract_narration:
The Supreme Court of the United States is one of the most powerful institutions within the American political system – exercising authority over life, liberty, and property. While granted these powers by law and political tradition, the Court’s legitimacy in making these weighty decisions rests, in no small part, on the public accepting that the Court is “above” politics. In other words, despite creating “winners” and “losers” when issuing decisions, ordinary people seem to believe two things: (1) the Court’s members were chosen via fair, democratic processes, and (2) differences in opinion are due to conflicting Constitutional interpretations rather than the naked partisan preferences of Justices. These assumptions, however, have been sorely tested in recent years. From brutal, polarized confirmation hearings to questions about candidates’ fitness to serve, and controversial, highly visible decisions, some citizens may not see the Court as the same backstop for democratic values that it was in the mid-20th Century. These developments raise thorny questions about the sources of public support for the Supreme Court more generally. We investigate whether citizens’ democratic beliefs are connected to their views about the Court’s legitimacy, and, in turn, whether those attitudes are affected by the Court’s decisions.

To explore the relationship between public views about democracy and their support for the Court, this research will deploy a four-wave panel survey that will allow researchers to (1) test whether democratic values correspond to diffuse support via a rigorous panel design and, (2) analyze whether highly salient decisions affect the Court’s legitimacy, generally, and whether such decisions affect the relationship between democratic values and Court support, specifically. By collecting a combination of original survey, panel, and experimental data, this research supplies a rare opportunity to obtain contemporaneous public reactions to a series of high-profile decisions that the Court will most likely issue during the summer of 2022, which bookends a period of sincere political and democratic upheaval. Despite political scientists’ concern about democratic backsliding, insufficient attention has been paid to the role of the judiciary in deepening public cynicism about democracy. This research not only represents a significant step forward in understanding basic theories of why citizens respect the Supreme Court’s legitimacy, but it offers a chance to analyze how a potentially counter-majoritarian political institution may be contributing to this country’s ongoing crisis of democracy.

por.por_cntn:
Given America’s rising tide of partisan polarization, and political events since 2016, we propose that the relationship between the Supreme Court and the mass public requires reassessment. Our work is grounded in the results of  nationally representative, five-wave panel study conducted between May 2022 (before Roe v. Wade’s overturning) and May 2023, alongside several original survey experiments. Our key finding is that the perceived legitimacy of the Court has durably and meaningfully sorted and polarized: Democrats’ diffuse support for the Court has careened downwards – becoming deeply negative and accompanied by a cynicism of Justices’ motivations and intuitions – while Republican support remains consistent and positive. After presenting our preliminary findings at two academic conferences, we have drafted multiple articles now submitted for potential publication in leading academic journals. We also intend to publish a scholarly monograph based on this research. 

 

In an era of global democratic backsliding and rising illiberalism, scholars have cast a wide net studying the health of democratic governments and their attendant institutions. One important finding in this growing body of works involves the role of federal courts as an important indicator of democratic trouble – the loss of respect for judiciaries and extrajudicial reform of them are often highlighted as precursors to democratic backsliding. As Americanists, our work turns the lens inwards to better understand whether the loss of Court legitimacy in the United States hints at deeper fractures in support for democracy more broadly within the public. 

 

Our research begins by contextualizing how diffuse support for the Court has ebbed and flows over time. Pairing our original panel data collection with older surveys of diffuse support for democracy, we construct a new dataset of Supreme Court polling that reveals how cleanly and dramatically Democrats and Republicans have diverged in the legitimacy they extend to the Court. In the aftermath of the 2016 election, Democrats began to register lower ratings of diffuse support, culminating in a bottoming out of support in the aftermath of the Dobbs decision in mid-2022.   

 

But do these developments constitute a “crisis” for American democracy? Perhaps not as much as might be expected given the way in which a loss of support for judicial institutions oftentimes unfolds. Our analysis reveals that the relationship between support for abstract democratic values and support for the Supreme Court is exceedingly weak. In contrast to the expectations of past research, these democratic “values” do not underpin respect for the Court – in no small part due to overwhelming partisan consensus involving support for democracy, generally. Further, while obedience to the law is correlated with diffuse support for the Court, we illustrate that such views also exhibit partisan sorting in their relation to legitimacy. Support for the “rule of law” is sometimes couched as a democratic value, we instead demonstrate that it both resembles canonical measures of authoritarianism and closely corresponds to liberal-conservative preferences. 

 

Our findings do not show that American Democrats have given up on democracy and its institutions. Rather, we argue that perceived legitimacy of a particular institution ought better to be conceived of as an ongoing, running tally in a citizen’s mind of both the institution’s performance, as well as the process by which the institution renders its judgments. The Supreme Court’s policy performance since 2016 has decidedly favored conservative interests. And the process by which the Court’s membership turned over could be viewed by Democrats as driven by partisan and ideological goals. This combination, alongside the lack of electoral accountability to reign in an institution that has produced such outputs, combine to explain why this previously durable commitment to one of America’s three branches of government has waned so dramatically among liberal citizens.

 

In sum, this research documents how a wave of social sorting and polarization that washes across American politics no longer excludes the perceived legitimacy of the Supreme Court. Diffuse support for the Court once solidly buttressed its ability to engage in counter-majoritarian policymaking and assert its autonomy from the other branches of government, we now witness serious calls from progressive politicians and commentators urging President Biden to ignore conservative rulings wholesale. Today, the Court no longer functions as a counterweight against illiberal tendencies, empowering a numerical minority when it comes to achieving unpopular political victories. These tensions have serious consequences for democracy in the sense that a durable, sustained loss of legitimacy encourages further fracturing in the way in which the United States’ separated powers interact.
